Suppose that a town has two hotels, Hotel A and Hotel B. It is known that on any given night, 60% of the tourists who stay at Hotel A will return to Hotel A on their next visit, while 40% will switch to Hotel B. Similarly, 70% of tourists who stay at Hotel B will return to Hotel B on their next visit, while 30% will switch to Hotel A. 

If there are currently 100 tourists staying at Hotel A and 200 tourists staying at Hotel B, what is the probability that on the next night there will be exactly 150 tourists staying at Hotel A and 150 staying at Hotel B?
message_2:
Let's use the binomial probability formula to solve this problem. The binomial probability formula is:

P(x) = C(n, x) * p^x * (1-p)^(n-x)

where P(x) is the probability of x successes in n trials, C(n, x) is the number of combinations of n items taken x at a time, p is the probability of success, and (1-p) is the probability of failure.

In this case, we want to find the probability that exactly 50 tourists from Hotel A switch to Hotel B and exactly 100 tourists from Hotel B switch to Hotel A.

For Hotel A:
n = 100 (number of tourists)
x = 50 (number of tourists switching to Hotel B)
p = 0.4 (probability of switching to Hotel B)

For Hotel B:
n = 200 (number of tourists)
x = 100 (number of tourists switching to Hotel A)
p = 0.3 (probability of switching to Hotel A)

Now, we can calculate the probabilities for each hotel separately:

P(50 tourists from Hotel A switch to Hotel B) = C(100, 50) * 0.4^50 * 0.6^50
P(100 tourists from Hotel B switch to Hotel A) = C(200, 100) * 0.3^100 * 0.7^100

To find the probability of both events happening simultaneously, we multiply the two probabilities:

P(150 tourists in Hotel A and 150 tourists in Hotel B) = P(50 tourists from Hotel A switch to Hotel B) * P(100 tourists from Hotel B switch to Hotel A)

Using a calculator or software to compute the binomial coefficients and probabilities, we get:

P(150 tourists in Hotel A and 150 tourists in Hotel B) â‰ˆ 0.0461

So, the probability that on the next night there will be exactly 150 tourists staying at Hotel A and 150 staying at Hotel B is approximately 4.61%.
